detaileddescription.para: Converts a decibel (dB) value into a volume level suitable for SOUND VOLUME. The return value is always in the range 0–255, where:

sect3.title: What are decibels?
sect3.para: Decibels are a way of describing relative loudness. They don’t measure sound directly, but how much quieter or louder something is compared to a reference point:

listitem.para: 0 dB means “no change” - the sound plays at its original level.
Negative values (e.g. -6 dB, -12 dB) make the sound quieter.
The further the number is below zero, the quieter the result.
Positive values are not useful here. Anything above 0 dB is clamped to maximum.

sect3.para: For example, -6 dB is a common setting to “turn something down a bit” (50% loudness in Retro Rocket) without muting it.

sect3.title: Behaviour in Retro Rocket
sect3.para: Values above 0 are treated as 0 dB. Values below –60 are treated as silence.
This gives a simple but natural way to think about volume, since each –6 dB step roughly halves the loudness.

listitem.para: Use DECIBELS() when you want to set volume in familiar dB terms instead of raw 0–255 values.
The mapping is not linear: small changes near 0 dB make a noticeable difference, while changes at very low levels fade smoothly towards silence.
Internally this uses a fast lookup table, so performance is constant time.
